body: I have no explanation as to why the DAG runs started on 2014-08-02. My `-s` was clearly 2014-08-06.
Note: this was on 1.6.2

+1 This feature would be really useful. Basically, any DAG that doesn't use incremental date-based partitioning would benefit from this.

A trivial example is a DAG that simply snapshots a full DB and loads it into a BLOB store. If it runs once, you're caught up. If you have the DAG set to run hourly, and miss an hour for whatever reason, there's no point in snapshotting the DB and loading it back-to-back. Just run the latest one, and skip the rest.
![20160226173639](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/179343/13348637/8dbf4914-dcaf-11e5-8266-bf468cda6563.jpg)
Right now, I just can set the max_active_runs to 1 for solve this scenario. T_T

I've suggested this only as an improvement. 

Calling the table 'user' doesn't stop Airflow from working with a postgres backend, but 'user' is considered a reserved word in postgres that should not be used for table names. If I log on to the postgres shell:

`select * from user;`

returns the postgres current_user (not the airflow users).  To see the airflow users, I need to:

`select * from "user";`

So the users are there and airflow is still working, but from perspective of development/debug/best practice, I am suggesting that renaming this table would be an improvement (not a necessity).

OK, thanks, I'll do that.

It looks like the cleanup step in setup.py is not working and a file which was removed from the repo at some point (airflow/www/templates/admin/base.html) is remaining in the build directory which is not being deleted and then being installed even though it's no longer in the repo. 

A clean repo, clearing the build artifacts,  or removing that file from the installation solves the issue. Maybe you could have a step at the beginning of setup.py that deletes existing build artifacts.

```
(airflow) [airflow@usw2dbdpag02 airflow]$ git status
# On branch gd_prod_1.6.2.3
nothing to commit (working directory clean)
(airflow) [airflow@usw2dbdpag02 airflow]$ ls -lha airflow/www/templates/admin/
total 12K
drwxr-xr-x. 2 airflow airflow 4.0K Feb 25 23:33 .
drwxr-xr-x. 4 airflow airflow 4.0K Feb 25 23:33 ..
-rw-r--r--. 1 airflow airflow 2.5K Feb 25 23:33 master.html
(airflow) [airflow@usw2dbdpag02 airflow]$ ls -lha build/lib/airflow/www/templates/admin/
total 16K
drwxr-xr-x. 2 airflow airflow 4.0K Feb 25 23:33 .
drwxr-xr-x. 4 airflow airflow 4.0K Feb 25 23:04 ..
-rw-r--r--. 1 airflow airflow 3.8K Feb 25 23:04 base.html
-rw-r--r--. 1 airflow airflow 2.5K Feb 25 23:33 master.html

```

I feel like all these attributes aren't guaranteed to be present and that the framework will choke trying to template missing attributes. The contract of what one should provide is unclear.

If they are required, they should be explicitly defined in the constructor header (with defaults), and stamped into `self` in **init**.py.

I read the way things are organized in the hook and operator and it's a bit messy the way kwargs is passed around. I saw how you overrode the **get_attriubte** is a bit hacky too. The operator doesn't have a good doc string to compensate for this behavior... Consider making a clearer interface to the operator, or documenting its expected behavior in the doc string.

You must have some funky object attached to your DAG that isn't deepcoypable. Looks at your callbacks, params, default_args and other ways to reference external objects. 

In Flask's debug mode it's easy-ish to track down which object is at fault.

The deepcopy is used to get subsections of DAGs without altering the original DagBag. We could eventually refactor the code so that copies would be made by loading up a fresh targeted DagBag but since we use the python import system we'd have to play some tricks to it to force a re-import.
Cool .. thanks for the debug mode tip ... running in debug now hoping to track down the issue.
Merging since it's contrib and Travis CI passed.

I'm not quite understanding the exception/bubble comment, yes I'd normally want to know about any and all failures (certainly in this case I'd normally want the DAG to halt and not run B.
That still leaves the issues of "should a cleared task clear the xcom_pushes"?

I met this problem in CentOS when add new workers
yum install mysql-devel
sovled my problem.

On Mon, Feb 22, 2016 at 11:02 PM, Dmitriy Lee notifications@github.com
wrote:

> You don't need a full MySQL running locally if you use remote metadata
> store. All you need is development libs/headers. On linux based systems you
> can get them by doing
> sudo apt-get install libmysqlclient-dev -y . That's all you need to make pip
> install airflow[mysql] work.
> 
> If you use Macs for local development then the easiest way to get these
> libraries is by using homebrew. Install homebrew then tun brew install
> mysql-connector-c then pip install airflow[mysql]
> 
> May be it can be added to FAQ (instead of installation docs) as I suspect
> many folks run into this mysql_config not found issue when trying to
> setup remote MySQL based metadata store
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/1047#issuecomment-187220975.

## 

Best Wishes from TonyLee.

after that, install python mysql connector
`pip install "mysqlclient>=1.3.6"`

@nicktrav Add a few minor comments. Once fixed, ping me on gitter and I will merge it.

@zigeuner 

To set a new start date, you should rename your DAG. I use the convention `my_dag_v1`, `my_dag_v2`, `my_dag_v3`. This is documented on https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/wiki/Airflow-Common-Pitfalls

It is not ideal and we are starting to discuss better way to set this dynamically. For now, that is your work-around. 

Additionally, as mentioned here, 999 is the limit for SQLite: 
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7106016/too-many-sql-variables-error-in-django-witih-sqlite3/8433514#8433514

SQLite is okay for initially getting your system up, but we recommend using a DB that more closely mimics your production and qa deployments. DBs like mysql, postgresql do not impose limits in the IN-clause, though I am not sure about limits on host parameters. In either case, we leave to SQLAlchemy, our ORM and it's DB driver providers to solve the details of each DB.

As mentioned on https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/1069, this is a wontfix since it is likely a bug in SQLAlchemy's support of SQLite and because we recommend folks to move to a DB similar to what they would use in QA and Production envs.
Added to https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/wiki/Airflow-Common-Pitfalls
@criccomini See above.. might be in your wheel house.

I wasn't aware that the backfill does not reset/edit DagRun. That seems unintuitive to me as my understanding was that the backfill and run commands delegate to executors and that DagRun reflected work executors did, not work the scheduler needs to do. It makes sense now because I know the internals of the code, but it actually doesn't make sense to a user of the system. 

DagRuns should be a complete view of what has or will be executed. cc @mistercrunch @criccomini 

I'm changing this issue's title to reflect what I think is a bug/enhancement.

Hi Maxime, 

I do agree with your concerns. Actually we didn't wanted to add dozens of new operators like `QuboleHiveOperator`, `QuboleHadoopOperator` etc, so we'd to do hacks like that. If we had individual command operators like I said above, then we could adhere to simple design like the other operators have. 

So either I can try to write down the behaviour in more better way, or you can suggest me some alternative approach for supporting templates?

Thanks,
Sumit

@pedrorjbr I do this in the DAG below. I have a BranchPythonOperator, similar to the ShortCircuitOperator you use above. In my case, my `check_for_time_to_build_model_branch_condition` BranchPythonOperator, branch left or right, and then skips the other side. My join happens in `wait_for_previous_hour`. My Join Operator specifies a `trigger_rule='one_success',` ``` wait_for_previous_hour = ExternalTaskSensor( task_id='wait_for_previous_hour', trigger_rule='one_success', external_dag_id=DAG_NAME, external_task_id='send_email_notification_flow_successful', allowed_states=['success'], execution_delta=timedelta(hours=1), dag=dag) ``` As @mistercrunch mentions, just add a trigger rule to your `join` task. All you need to do for your case is something like: ``` join_op = DummyOperator( task_id='join', trigger_rule='one_success', dag=dag) ``` Hope this helps. I'm closing this. If you need to re-open, ping me on gitter.

Actually, I may have reproduced the issue. Could it be because `retries` are set to 0? If so the behavior is still surprising since we force the retry?

(retires are dealt by the task itself)

Hi @krisskross 

In reading this issue, I am encountering conflicting reports. 

On one hand, you report `When tasks fail and are marked as "up_for_retry" in the UI the scheduler never picks them up and retries them?` and on the other hand, you report `Actually, I may have reproduced the issue. Could it be because retries are set to 0? If so the behavior is still surprising since we force the retry?`

So, if you are running the release version, there was a known bug in which we had infinite retries, though that only happened if the retries was set to a number above 0. If retries was set to 0, then no retries would happen -- that is by design since you are asking for 0 retries. At this point, I need a pretty clear definition of the issue. If you want a finite number of retries, set the count above 0 and run the latest code. If you are okay with running infinite retries until success, then set the value above 0 and run the release version (1.6.2). If you don't want retries, set it to 0 on any version.
Yes, i'm toying around with airflow 1.6.2 at the moment to see if it fits our needs. So I might have confused two different dags. I will try retries = 1. Thanks.

I changed the scheduling to `1 0,5 * * *` to check whether te issue is related to changing of the date at 12 am. However it doesn't fix the issue. This is what happened today:

```
[2016-03-01 00:01:03,294] {local_executor.py:29} INFO - LocalWorker running airflow run my_dag start 2016-02-29T05:01:00 --local -sd DAGS_FOLDER/my_dag.py
[2016-03-01 05:01:03,283] {local_executor.py:29} INFO - LocalWorker running airflow run my_dag start 2016-03-01T00:01:00 --local -sd DAGS_FOLDER/my_dag.py 
```

Unfortunately, setting `retries` to 1 as global default did not help. Here's my dag.

``` py
default_args = {
    'owner': 'airflow',
    'depends_on_past': False,
    'start_date': datetime(2016, 2, 24),
    'retries': 1,
    'retry_delay': timedelta(minutes=5)
}

t1 = BashOperator(

  dag=dag)
```

I think I've got a clue - in the webserver logs process_file is aborting on an exception, so it's returning None rather than found_dags (my line numbers will be a bit off due to debug)

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/airflow/lib/python3.4/site-packages/airflow/models.py", line 213, in process_file
    with utils.timeout(30):
  File "/opt/airflow/lib/python3.4/site-packages/airflow/utils.py", line 620, in __enter__
    signal.signal(signal.SIGALRM, self.handle_timeout)
ValueError: signal only works in main thread
```

Removing the `with utils.timeout(30):` wrapper from process_file fixes this error but I'm sure it's not the best approach!

@mistercrunch The only potential issue that I have seen is the `apply_default` decorator. It now needs to be imported from `airflow.utils.decorators`, and so it depends how custom written operators have been written.

It should be a quick fix though.

This bug should be fixed in `master`. I added try statements inside the timeout context manager so that it goes disabled when using LocalExecutor or other subprocesses. 

This timeout is important as it makes sure that if a pipeline takes a long time to parse (say someone would run a Hive job in the python code of the pipeline instead of using an operator), the script times out after 30 seconds and all the other pipelines can move on. Without the timeout, a bad actor could hold up the scheduler for long periods.

We may want to take a different, more generic approach to timeouts eventually, but I the current approach should be good. Closing.

At some point in the past year, Flask-login changed the `is_authenticated()` to an `is_authenticated` property on the user class.

There is a workaround suggested in the stackoverflow question below that might work if implemented in your custom ldap_backend.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33274337/how-to-call-is-authenticated-in-flask-login

For the reference on the Flask-login change:
https://github.com/maxcountryman/flask-login/blob/master/CHANGES#L43

I think right now how concurrency works is by checking how many running task instances in database, which means it's possible all tasks can start running at the same time because when they query the database, they all get a count of 0

that seems to make sense based on what i see.  i've been using pools as a better way to control concurrency, but it gets annoying because the creation/management of a pool isn't easily expressed in the DAG itself, like the `concurrency` and `max_active_runs` parameters are.
Merged, thanks!

Downgraded flask_admin to 0.2.11 and we're good. This isn't the ideal solution but workable for now. 

Thanks for the help.

Yes.. I think the airflow guys should query the number of running tasks from the executor .e.g. celery executor before queuing task_instance into the executor. Since it's in memory, they are guaranteed to get the most updated count. But this maybe a problem if you run some tasks over cli because that will be another executor

@mistercrunch are you still considering this?

I reproduced this bug in the LocalExecutor with some test code. **1. My Example Code** ``` from airflow.operators import BashOperator, DummyOperator from airflow.models import DAG from datetime import datetime, timedelta seven_days_ago = datetime.combine(datetime.today() - timedelta(7), datetime.min.time()) args = { 'owner': 'airflow', 'depends_on_past': False, 'start_date': seven_days_ago, } dag = DAG( dag_id='example_concur', default_args=args, concurrency= 1, schedule_interval='0 0 * * *', dagrun_timeout=timedelta(minutes=60)) task = BashOperator( task_id='task', bash_command='echo "starting - "; sleep 15; echo "done"', dag=dag) ``` **2. Steps to Reproduce A. Once the DAG is loaded, it should run 7 daily DAG Runs** **B. Clear the DAG** **C. You will see the first run start running and the other 6 runs will be queued!** **D. Once the first one completes, the other 6 will all start running in parallel** **E. Then they all complete**

I've confirmed this bug only occurs when `depends_on_past=False` -- essentially, `concurrency` is not honored for `depends_on_past=False` but is honored for `depends_on_past=True` When I set `depends_on_past=True`, I observe the correct, expected behavior below:

Here is the code with depends_on_past = True but actually will have multiple task instance running at the same time.

```
num_of_tasks = 30

default_args = {
    'owner': 'lucafuji',
    'depends_on_past': True,
    'start_date': datetime(2016, 3, 1),
    'end_date': datetime(2016, 3, 3)
}


def sleep_30(**kwargs):
    logger.info("My task id is {}".format(kwargs['task'].task_id))
    time.sleep(30)

dag = DAG(dag_id="concurrency_test", default_args=default_args,concurrency=1)
for i in range(0, num_of_tasks):
    tid = "sleep_task_{}".format(i)
    task = PythonOperator(dag=dag, task_id=tid, python_callable=sleep_30, provide_context=True)
```
@lucafuji Thanks, though i already provided an example of one above. Also, please test with `depends_on_past:True`. Additionally, I'm testing on HEAD Master.
If you have a fix in mind, please feel free to submit a PR. I'd be happy to review it.

@syvineckruyk I can reliably reproduce mine, and the debug window gives me a different, more obvious error:
`TypeError: can't pickle generator objects`

The object in question is my custom `Operator` that has a generator attached to it because it reads from HDFS.  Still not totally clear on what's being serialized and why, but I think the call we both see to `object.__new__()` might lead you to a clue.  I'd bet that `thread.lock` is not serializable, and it's attached to your DAG.

But like I said before, I'm not really sure how to handle this, because I need the custom Operator to continue to use its generator.

@bolkedebruin `snakebite` has a new release https://pypi.python.org/pypi/snakebite/ and I just verified that it includes the PR I mentioned. 

And in https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/setup.py#L56, it has `hdfs = ['snakebite>=2.4.13']` so it should install the latest `snakebite` :)
But it won't install a new version. 2.7.8 is now required for existing installations. So it does need to be updated.
